Yuddha Kanda
==================================================

Chapter: 1
Verse: 1
Content: Touched with joy to hear the words rightly spoken by Hanuman, Rama replied as
follows: -
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 2
Content: "A very outstanding work, the most arduous in the world has been done by Hanuman,
which could not be carried out even in thought by any other on the surface of this earth."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 3
Content: "Indeed, I cannot perceive as such anyone other than Garuda (chief of the feathered
race and vehicle of Lord Vishnu), wind- god and Hanuman, who can cross the mighty ocean."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 4
Content: "Who can return alive, having entered (once) taking refuge only in self- command,
the city of Lanka, which is unconquerable by gods demons and Yakshas and even by Gandharvas, Nagas
and ogres and well under the custody of Ravana?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 5
Content: "Who is able to capture that citadel, by assault, that is exceedingly dangerous to
be attacked and which is powerfully guarded by ogres, but one whose courage and valour are equal to
Hanuman's?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 6
Content: "A great act of service has been done by Hanuman to Sugriva thus by exhibiting his
strength corresponding to his pace."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 7
Content: "That servant to whom his master entrusts a difficult task and who performs it with
zeal is said to be a superior person."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 8
Content: "The one who is ready and capable but who yet does no more than his master extracts
from him is called a mediocre person."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 9
Content: "The one who is well and able and yet does not carry out the instructions of his
master as directed is said to be the least of men ."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 10
Content: "Through the discovery of Sita's retreat by this faithful messenger, Hanuman has
fulfilled the task entrusted to him unfalteringly to the satisfaction of Sugriva and hence there
was no diminution to his self."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 11
Content: "By finding out Sita, the Raghu dynasty as well as myself and the valiant Lakshmana
too, have been rightly saved today."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 12
Content: "But it squeezes my conscience further, hopeless as I am, to think that I am not
able to do a pleasant act befittingly to the bearer of these good tidings."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 13
Content: "Let me at least embrace this magnanimous Hanuman since in the present
circumstances, this is all that is easily obtained from me."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 14
Content: Thus saying, Rama vibrating with joy, clasped Hanuman in his arms who, master of
himself, his mission fulfilled, had returned.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 15
Content: After reflecting a while, Rama the great scion of Raghus, again spoke as follows,
Sugriva the ruler of monkeys too listening attentively.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 16
Content: "The search for Sita has been performed so much well in all ways. But my mind gets
dejected once more, when I behold this vast ocean."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 17
Content: How can these monkeys put together will reach the southern bank of the ocean, which
is so difficult to cross and which contains voluminous water?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 18
Content: "Having received the tidings of Sita, what can now be done to take the monkeys to
the farther side the sea?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 1
Verse: 19
Content: Thus speaking to Hanuman, Rama the destroyer of enemies and the mighty armed, was
filled with apprehension and then became absorbed in thought.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 1
Content: The glorious Sugreeva made the following reply, which was intended to expel his
grief, to Rama the son of Dasaratha who felt miserable with anguish.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 2
Content: "Oh, hero! Why are you lamenting thus, as any other ordinary man? Do not be
sorrowful like this. Abandon your grief, as an ungrateful man abandons friendship."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 3
Content: "As the information about Seetha has since been gathered, I do not indeed see any
scope for your grief Oh, Rama!"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 4
Content: "Oh, Rama! You are a wise person, a knower of sacred works, an intellectual and a
learned man. Give up these ordinary apprehensions like a man whose spirit is disciplined gives up
ideas which spoil the purpose.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 5
Content: "We shall make our way up to Lanka, by crossing the ocean filled with large
crocodiles. We shall destroy your enemy."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 6
Content: "All action get dissipated by a person who is non-enthusiastic, depressed and
disturbed with grief. Such a person gets into troubles too."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 7
Content: "These leaders of monkey squads are gallant and efficient in all ways. They are
enthusiastic even to enter a fire for your sake. I understand this from their joy and my reasoning
too is sound."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 8
Content: "You ought to act in every way that I may be able to get back Seetha, after
destroying by an attack the enemy Ravana of sinful deeds."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 9
Content: "You take steps in such a way that a bridge is constructed across the sea and we
reach that city of the king of ogres."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 10
Content: "Be certain that Ravana is killed, once he is seen in a battle and on our seeing
that city of Lanka standing on a peak of the Trikuta Mountain."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 11
Content: "Without building a bridge across the sea, the dreadful abode of Varuna (the god of
water), Lanka cannot be defeated even by gods and demons including Indra."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 12
Content: "Know that when the whole of my army crosses the sea as a bridge is built across it,
they will come out victorious, because these monkeys who are able to change their form at will are
indeed valiant in battle."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 14
Content: "Therefore, take away your apprehensive mind, which destroys any enterprise for
grief in this world diminishes the might of a man, Oh king!"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 15
Content: ï¿½Cling to the practice of boldness, ought to be resorted to by a man. It will
produce competence without doubt to the doer quickly."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 16
Content: "Prevail upon the strength with alertness at this moment, Oh highly intelligent
prince! Grief for something lost or destroyed consumes all resources of even the strong and
magnanimous men like you."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 17
Content: "You are the foremost among the intelligent and the knower of all sacred texts.
Hence, you ought to defeat the enemy, with allies like me."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 18
Content: "I do not indeed see any one who can withstand you in a battle filed in the three
worlds, when you are armed with a bow, Oh Rama!"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 19
Content: "You work duly entrusted to the monkeys will not be spoiled. You shall behold Seetha
era imperishable sea."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 20
Content: "Oh, Lord of the earth! Desist from this melancholy. Yield to your legitimate
indignation. Unadventurous Kshatriyas (members of warrior-tribe) never win honor but all fear the
wrathful."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 21
Content: "You with your resourceful mind, along with us together, ponder over now a design to
cross the sea, the terrible Lord of rivers."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 22
Content: "Know victory to be certain, once the sea has been crossed by the army. Verily when
all my forces have passed over the sea our triumph is assured!"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 23
Content: "These monkeys, the courageous soldiers who are able to change their form at their
volition, will crush their opponents with an avalanche of rocks and trees."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 24
Content: "Once we have crossed the sea (the abode of Varuna) by whatever the means employed,
Ravana is as definitely killed in my eyes, Oh exterminator of enemies!"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 2
Verse: 25
Content: What is the use of all these words? By all means, you will be a victorious man. I
see good omens and my heard is over thrilled with joy."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 1
Content: Hearing the well-founded and highly reasonable words of Sugreeva, Rama concurred
with him and spoke then to Hanuma as follows:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 2
Content: "I am competent of crossing this ocean by all means, either by way of austerity or
by forming a bridge or by drying up the ocean."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 3
Content: "Tell me how many citadels in Lanka are difficult of access, Oh, Hanuma! I desire to
know all that, as though viewed with an eye."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 4
Content: "You had the opportunity to catch a glimpse of the size of the army, the
fortification-details of the gates and citadels, the way in which Lanka was guarded and the various
mansions of ogres. Describe everything in accordance with facts, for you are skilled in all
ways."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 6
Content: Hearing the words of Rama, Hanuma the son of wind-god, who was excellent in the art
of expression, forthwith spoke once more to Rama as follows:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 7
Content: "Listen to me! I shall tell you everything-how the city of Lanka has been defended
by the various methods of fortification and how it has been guarded by the troops."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 8
Content: "I shall tell you the details of how the ogres are attached to their king, the
excellent prosperity of Lanka generated by the glory of Ravana, the awfulness of the ocean, the
division of the body of his forces and of animals like horses and elephants carrying his forces
other than the infantry." Saying so, Hanuma the foremost among monkeys, who knew the truth narrated
as follows.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 10
Content: "The great Lanka was rejoiced and gayful, full of elephants in rut, abounding in
chariots and inhabited by gangs of ogres."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 11
Content: "Four fairly big and extensive gates are fitted with strong doors along with huge
beams for locking those gates."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 12
Content: "Strong and mighty ballista capable of hurling darts and stones have been attached
to them. The enemy troops which arrive there are warded off by those catapults at the very
gates."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 13
Content: "Dangerous and sharp edged Sataghnis made of iron, forged by hordes of ogres, have
been kept in readiness in hundreds at the gates.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 14
Content: "A great rampart made of gold, which is difficult to assail with violence and is
inlaid at intervals with gems, corals, cat's eyes and pearls, encircle that Lanka."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 15
Content: "Most awe-inspiring and fathomless moats (deep trenches) of great splendor, filled
with cold water, infested with alligators and inhabited by fishes are there all round the
city."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 16
Content: "Anterior to the gateways, there are four very extensive draw-bridges, equipped with
numerous engines and furnished with many rows of buildings (built on the rampart and meant for
those entrusted with the duty of guarding the entrances)."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 17
Content: "Against the approach of the enemy forces there, the draw-bridges are protected by
the aforesaid engines and the enemy-battalions are flung into the moats on every side."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 18
Content: "The most important draw-bridge which is unshakable, firmly fastened very well and
strong, is dazzling with numerous gold pillars and pedestals."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 19
Content: "Ravana, inclined to war and endowed with powers of the state, himself remains alert
and in readiness to review the forces, Oh, Rama!"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 20
Content: "Lanka therefore is impregnable, it is a celestial citadel, that inspires terror.
Surrounded by water and built on a mountain, it has four fold defenses including forest and
artificial fortification."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 21
Content: "Lanka is situated on the other side of the ocean, which is difficult of access, Oh
Rama! It offers no passage for vehicles either and there is no proper communication from all
sides."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 22
Content: "That city of Lanka, resembling the city of Gods, is built on a mountain peak and is
inaccessible. That Lanka is abound with horses and elephants and is extremely difficult to
conquer."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 23
Content: Deep trenches and Sataghnis too as well as engines of war of every kind adorn Lanka
the city of wicked Ravana."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 24
Content: "Ten thousand ogres all carrying darts in their hands and warriors contending with
swords, who are difficult to assail, are positioned at the eastern gate."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 25
Content: "One hundred thousand of ogres, with an army of four limbs (viz. horses, foot
soldiers, elephants and chariots) are positioned at the southern gate of the city. Warriors
unsurpassed by others constitute that army."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 26
Content: One million troops arrived with shields and swords as well as proficient in the use
of all mystic missiles, are positioned at the western gate."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 27
Content: "A hundred millions of ogres, who are mounted in chariots or who ride on hoses, sons
of distinguished families and greatly honored, are positioned there at the northern gate."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 28
Content: "Moreover, ogres hundreds of thousands in number, difficult to attack, aggregating
to one and quarter of a crore of ogres are positioned at the central division."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 29
Content: "Those bridges were broken by me and the moats were filled up (with the wreckage).
The city of Lanka was burnt by me and the defensive walls were pulled down. A part of the army of
the gigantic ogres was destroyed."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 30
Content: "By some way or other, let us cross the ocean. The city of Lanka should be assumed
then as destroyed by the monkeys."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 31
Content: "Oh, Rama! What is the use for the rest of the forces to you? Angada, Divida,
Mainda, Jambavan, Panasa, Anala and Nila the commander-in-chief alone, by reaching that great city
of Ravana leaping and storming Lanka with its mountains and woods, moats and archways, protective
walls and buildings, will recover Seetha."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 3
Verse: 34
Content: "Order quickly to get all the forces accumulated accordingly. Let us set out at the
appropriate moment."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 1
Content: Rama, a very bright man and a true warrior, having duly heard the words of Hanuman from 
the beginning, thereafter spoke as follows:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 2
Content: "I shall destroy quickly Lanka, the city of that terrible ogre (Ravana), of which you 
just informed I am really telling this."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 3
Content: "Be pleased to approve our march at this moment, a suitable moment for success. The sun 
reached the mid-day.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 4
Content: "Let that ogre go (to his abode) after kidnapping Seetha. Where will he go alive? Hearing 
of my march to Lanka, Seetha will get back her hope in life, like a sick man having drunk poison touches 
ambrosia at the end of his life."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 5
Content: "This northern planet of Phalguni will be in conjunction with the Hasta star tomorrow. 
Hence, let us depart today itself with all the troops accompanying us, Oh, Sugreeva!"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 6
Content: "By seeing the omens which are becoming visible, I deduce that I shall bring back Seetha 
the daughter of Janaka, by killing Ravana."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 7
Content: "My eye which is twitching on the upper lid, is proclaiming as it were, my desire of 
victory coming nearer."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 8
Content: Then Rama the virtuous man versed in moral law, who was well-adored by Sugreeva the king 
of monkeys and Lakshmana, again spoke as follows:-
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 9
Content: "Let general Nila accompanied by strength of hundred thousand warriors go before the 
army, to explore the way."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 10
Content: "Oh Nila the chief of Army! Steer the army speedily by the path, abound with fruits and 
roots, cool woods and fresh water and honey."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 11
Content: "The evil-minded demons may spoil the roots, fruits and water in the path-way. You always 
try to be on you guard."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 12
Content: "Let the monkeys jump into law grounds, into places made inaccessible by forest-grores 
and into thickets and notice whether any rival forces are stationed there."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 13
Content: "Let whatever little of feeble forces stay back in Kishkindha, as our operation will 
indeed be dreadful. It has to be discharged daringly."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 14
Content: "Let the best of monkeys with great strength in hundreds and thousands lead the formidable 
of the army, which is akin to an oceanic stream."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 15
Content: "Let Gaja, equal to a mountain, Gavaya a very strong warrior and Gavaksha march in front, 
as a majestic bull marches in front of a cow-herd."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 16
Content: "Let the monkey called Rishabha, Lord of the simians and the best of the primates march 
forward, duly guarding the right side of the army of the simians."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 17
Content: "Let Gandhamadana, with a strength unconquerable like an elephant in rut, proceed duly 
guarding the left side of the army of monkeys."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 18
Content: "I myself, mounted on the shoulders of Hanuman, like Indra on Airavata, will march in 
the centre of my troops, duly cheering the multitude of army."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 19
Content: "Let this Lakshmana, resembling the lord of Death, march on the shoulders of Angada like 
Kubera the lord of riches and the sovereign of beings marches on an elephant called Sarvabhauma."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 20
Content: Let the highly strong, Jambavan with Sushena and the monkey called Vegadarshi, all three, 
guard the middle part of the army."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 21
Content: "Hearing the words of Rama, Sugreeva with great valour, the commander of forces and the 
lion among monkeys gave orders to the monkeys accordingly."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 22
Content: Then, all those troops of monkeys with great speed together raised up and quickly bounced 
from caves and mountain-tops.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 23
Content: Thereafter Rama the virtuous man, treated respectfully by Sugreeva and Lakshmana, moved 
towards southern direction, along with the army.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 24
Content: At that time, Rama went surrounded by monkeys, looking like elephants, numbering in hundreds, 
hundreds of thousands and crores.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 25
Content: That extensive army of monkeys followed Rama who was marching in the lead. All those 
monkeys maintained by Sugreeva were rejoicing with delight.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 26
Content: The monkeys, jumping overwhelmingly with roaring sound and jest fully playing musical 
instruments (like trumpets) marched towards southern direction.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 27
Content: They marched on, eating good-smelling honeys and fruits and carrying large branches bearing 
clusters of blossoms in multitude.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 28
Content: Wild monkeys would lift up and throw one another all of a sudden. Some others were hanging 
down and flying upwards. Some other monkeys were throwing down others.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 29
Content: Monkeys close to Rama were thus shouting, "To us, Ravana is worthy of killing and also 
the entire demons."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 30
Content: Rishabha, Nila, and the courageous Kumuda along with many monkeys were clearing up the 
path ahead.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 31
Content: Sugreeva the king of monkeys, Rama and Lakshmana the destroyers of enemies were moving 
in the centre along with many robust and terrible monkeys.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 32
Content: The heroic monkey satabali who was accompanied by ten crores of monkeys, standing alone 
firmly, guarded the whole army of monkeys.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 33
Content: Kesari with a retinue of a hundred crore, Panasa, Gaja and Arka along with many monkeys 
were protecting one flank of that army.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 34
Content: Keeping Sugreeva in front, Sushena and Jambavanta surrounded by many bears, protected 
the hinder part of that army.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 35
Content: Nila their chief of the army, the brave and the best among monkeys, the self controlled 
and the foremost among movable beings, was protecting atha army in every direction.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 36
Content: Valimukha, Prajangha, Jambha and Rabhasa the monkey were moving on all sides, urging 
the monkeys forward.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 37
Content: Those foremost among the monkeys, proud of their strength, thus marching with the army, 
saw the Sahya mountain the best of mountains joined with many small mountains, lakes fully abounding 
in flowers and eminent ponds.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 39
Content: That large army of monkeys, terrific like an ocean-flood cognizing the command of Rama 
which is frightfully enraging, having terror-stricken, abandoning the vicinity of towns and even villages, 
marched like a highly dreadful ocean with a great hoaring sound.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 41
Content: All those prominent and valiant monkeys were overwhelmingly jumping ahead, like fine 
horses being whipped, at the side of that Rama.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 42
Content: Rama and Lakshmana the best among men being carried on shoulders by Hanuman and Angada 
the two monkeys, were effulgent like the moon and the sun having come together in contact with two large 
planets (Jupiter and Venus).
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 43
Content: Thereafter, Rama the virtuous man, treated respectfully by Sugreeva and Lakshmana, moved 
towards southern direction, along with the army. Lakshmana, with a fully meaningful presence of mind, 
sitting on Angada, spoke the following auspicious words which were fully meaningful, to Rama.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 45
Content: "Killing Ravana fast and obtaining Seetha who was taken away, you will proceed to Ayodhya 
which is abundant by rich, having accomplished your purpose."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 46
Content: "I am seeing all grand good omens in the sky and the earth self-evident of your fulfillment, 
Oh Rama! The wind which is favorable, gentle beneficial and comfortable to the army is blowing alongside."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 47
Content: "These beasts and birds are uttering sonorous and sweet sounds. All the quarters are 
looking bright. Even the sun is clear."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 48
Content: "The planet of Venus with its bright light, born from the sage Bhrigu (a mind-born son 
of Brahma the creator) is hanging behind you. Dhruva, the very bright pole-star (which is recognized 
by the contiguity of the stars presided over by the seven Brahmana sages) is becoming clear. All the 
pure great sages having bright light are shining are shining around Dhruva star.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 50
Content: "The royal sage Trishanku, our paternal grand father, born in the high-souled Ikshvaku 
dynasty, is purely shining (as a star) in front, along with his family-priest."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 51
Content: "Visakha stars are shining clearly without any evil influence. This supreme constellation 
is of our Ikshvakus, the high-souled."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 52
Content: "The Mula constellation of the titans is badly aspected, in that it is touched by a comet 
risen with a tail of light and tormented by it."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 53
Content: "All this has come for the destruction of the titans, for, the star seized by death is 
oppressed by a planet in its last hour."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 54
Content: "The waters are crystal-clear, with good taste. The woodlands are laden with fruit. The 
fragrant air is not blowing much. Trees are bearing seasonal flowers."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 55
Content: "The armies of monkeys formed into different squadrons are looking highly splendid like 
the armies of celestials in the battle in which the demon Taraka was killed, Oh venerable one! Be pleased 
to see these good omens in this manner."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 56
Content: The delighted Lakshmana spoke thus, cheering up his brother. Then, the army of monkeys 
consisting of excellent bears and monkeys having their very nails and teeth as weapons, marched ahead, 
covering the entire earth.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 58
Content: The aweful dust raised by nails and claws of monkeys obscured the splendor of the sun 
and also covered the earth comprising of mountains forests and the atmosphere. The colossal monkey-army 
advanced, encompassing the southern region like a mass of cloud enveloping the sky.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 60
Content: While the army was crossing the entire river-currents uninterruptedly, the currents flowed 
invertedly for a distance of many yojanas.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 61
Content: The mighty army entered thoroughly into lakes containing clear water, mountains full 
of trees, plain-landed territories and forests laden with fruits from the middle, from the four sides, 
from across and from under.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 62
Content: The gigantic army marched, thoroughly covering the land. All of them with a wind-like 
aped went on, manifesting a joy in their faces.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 63
Content: For the sake of Rama, the monkeys with fully elevated pace vied with each other in high 
spirits, vigor and prowess. Out of pride born of prime youth, some made various gestures on the way.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 65
Content: Some wild monkeys there walked very speedily. In that manner, some others hovered highly. 
Some made noises, sounding "kila! kila!".
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 66
Content: Some monkeys lashed their tails. Some even stamped their feet. Some others, stretching 
their arms, broke off rocks and trees.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 67
Content: Some monkeys ascended mountain-peaks and uttered huge noises. Some others made lion's 
roars.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 68
Content: Some monkeys were crushing many webs of creepers by the jerks of their thighs. The valiant 
monkeys also played with rocks and trees, by stretching their limbs.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 69
Content: In that place, the land was covered splendidly by hundreds of thousands, by thousands 
and crores of monkeys, who were looking very dreadful.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 70
Content: That extensive monkey-army was marching day and night. All the monkeys ruled by Sugreeva 
were exceedingly pleased and cheerful. All were marching quickly, rejoicing for war. Those monkeys desirous 
of Seetha's release, did not halt even for a moment anywhere.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 72
Content: Then, those monkeys reached and climbed up a mountain called sahya with a full canopy 
of trees and filled with many kinds of beasts.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 73
Content: Rama too went along, seeing the wonderful woods, streams and cascades of Sahya and Malaya 
mountains.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 74
Content: The monkeys enjoyed the fruits of Champaka, Tilaka, mango, Praseka, Sindnvaara Timisa 
and Karaveera trees.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 75
Content: The monkeys enjoyed Ashoka, Karanja, Plaksa, Nyagrodha, Jambu, myrobalan and Naga trees.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 76
Content: Various kinds of forest-trees standing on enchanting plateaus, being shaken by gust of 
winds, poured out flowers on those monkeys.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4
Verse: 77
Content: A soft-touching breeze, refreshing as a sandal, blew while the bees hummed in the nectar-scented 
woods.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 4

Chapter: 16

Chapter: 16
Verse: 9
Content: "There is wealth in cows. There is fear for kinsmen. There is fickleness in women.

Chapter: 16

Verse: 11
Content: "As drops of water fallen on lotus leaves do not get clung to those leaves, so also
a friendship does not cling to vulgar ones."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 16
Verse: 12
Content: "As rainy clouds in autumn, even though thundering, cannot get the earth saturated

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 16
Verse: 13
Content: "As a honey bee, even though getting nectar from a flower, does not stick on to that

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 16
Verse: 14
Content: "As even though trying to drink nectar from a flower of grass, a honey bee cannot

Chapter: 16

Verse: 28

oppressed or arrogant, is to be protected by one who has a disciplined mind, even by abandoning
one's life."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 18
Verse: 29
Content: "If he does not protect rightly through his strength, by fear or by ignorance or by
desire, it is a sin to be reproached by the world."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 18
Verse: 30
Content: "If having not been protected, a refugee dies before the eyes of a man who is able
to protect him, the former takes along all his moral merit and goes."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 18
Verse: 31
Content: "In not protecting thus the persons who take refuge, there is a great blemish
involved in it. It does not bestow heaven. It destroys reputation. It devastates strength and
valor"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 18
Verse: 32
Content: "I will follow the excellent words of Kandu. It becomes a very righteous thing,
gives reputation, leads to heaven and the rewards appear consequently."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 18

Content: "He who seeks refuge in me just once, telling me that ï¿½I am yours', I shall give him
assurance of safety against all types of beings. This is my solemn pledge"
----------------------------------------

himself; I have given an assurance of safety to him. Bring him here."

Content: Hearing Rama' s words, Sugreeva the lord of monkeys, overwhelmed as he was with
cordial friendship, replied to Rama as follows:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 18
Verse: 36
Content: "O, Rama, who knows righteousness, the crest jewel among lords of the world! What
surprise is there in thinking that you, duly endowed with true essence of life and established in a

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 18
Verse: 37
Content: "My inmost spirit also feels Vibhishana to be a genuine person, he being well
examined from all angles, by act of inference and by his appearance."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 18

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 18

Content: While the assurance of protection having been given to Rama, the highly sagacious
Vibhishana the brother of Ravana bent down and glanced towards the earth.

Content: The virtuous Vibhishana descended joyously from the sky to the ground along with his
faithful companions and alighted in the vicinity of Rama.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 19
Verse: 3
Content: Thereafter, Vibhishana along with the four demons fell prostrate and spoke to Rama
the following words which were equitable suitable and delightful.
----------------------------------------

Content: "I am the younger brother of Ravana and was humiliated by him. I sought refuge in
you, who are the refuge for all the beings."

at your disposal."

demons."

Content: Thus asked then by Rama who was unwearied in action, Vibhishana started telling
about the detailed strength of Ravana.

Content: "O, Rama! You might have heard about Prahasta, his chief of army. He defeated

Chapter: 21

of the ocean or a death should occur to me today". Making that resolve he laid down by the ocean,
restraining his speech and with a pious disposition according to tradition.

nature, resorting to their eternal path."

Chapter: 22
Verse: 26
Content: "Therefore, I am fathomless and my nature is that it is impossible of being swum
across. It becomes unnatural if I am shallow. I am telling you the following device to cross
me."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 27
Content: "O, prince! Neither from desire nor ambition nor fear nor from affection, I am able
to solidify my waters inhabited by alligators."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 28
Content: "O, Rama! I shall make it possible to see that you are able to cross over. I will
arrange a place for the monkeys to cross me and bear with it. As far as the army crosses me, the
crocodiles will not be aggressive to them."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 29
Content: Then, Rama spoke to that ocean as follows: "Listen to me. This great arrow should
not go in vain. In which region should it be descended?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 30
Content: Hearing Rama's words and seeing that powerful arrow, the large splendid Ocean spoke
the following words to Rama:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 31
Content: "Towards my northern side, there is a holy place. It is well known as Drumatulya, in
the same way as you are well known to this world."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 32
Content: "Numerous robbers of fearful aspect and deeds, having the sinful Abhiras as their

----------------------------------------

Verse: 34
Content: Hearing those words of the high-soled Ocean, Rama released that excellent and

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 35
Content: The place where the arrow, whose splendor was akin to that of a thunder and a

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 36
Content: The earth there, pierced by the dart, then emitted a sound . The waters of the

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 37

Chapter: 22
Verse: 38

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 39
Content: That desert of Maru became famous in the three worlds. Rama (the son of Dasaratha),

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 41
Content: Due to granting of a boon by Rama, that desert of Maru became the most congenial

Chapter: 22
Verse: 43

----------------------------------------

Verse: 45
Content: "Let this greatly energetic monkey build a bridge across me. I can hold that bridge.

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22

Content: Monkeys constructed the bridge with trees having blossom at the end of their boughs.

Verse: 65

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 67
Content: In the same manner, on the second day twenty Yojanas of bridge were constructed

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 68
Content: Thus, on the third day twenty-one Yojanas of the bridge were constructed in the

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 69
Content: On the forth day, a further of twenty-two Yojanas were constructed by the dashing

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 70
Content: In that manner, on the fifth day, the monkeys working quickly constructed

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 71
Content: That Nala, the strong and illustrious son of Visvakarma and an excellent monkey

----------------------------------------

----------------------------------------

Verse: 74

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22
Verse: 75

Verse: 77
Content: Those thousand crores of monkeys in a great spectacle reached the other shore of the

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 22

injustice and non-value gain the fruit of offence of omission."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 9
Content: Living beings reap the fruit of good actions in this and in the other world.
However, he who remains diligently devoted to actions with a view to attaining sensuous pleasure
enjoys blessing even in this life."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 10
Content: "In such a situation, this act of pursuit of sensuous pleasure has been cherished in
his heart by the king and was approved by us. What violation is there in doing this daring act
against the enemy?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 11
Content: "Regarding the reason which you have adduced for marching all alone for the
encounter, I shall tell you what is irrelevant and not so good."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 12
Content: "How will you conquer, single-handed, that Rama by whom several mighty demons were
destroyed in Janasthana earlier."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 13
Content: "Are you not seeing those frightened demons (though highly energetic) who are now
staying in the City, but who were earlier conquered by Rama in Janasthana?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 14
Content: "Though you know that Rama, the son of Dsasratha, is like an enraged lion, you wish
to awaken a serpent, who is sleeping."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 15
Content: "Who would be competent to approach that Rama, who is forever shining with a
splendour, dangerous to catch-up and as unbearable as death?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 16
Content: "Standing face-to-face with that enemy is all remaining in doubt. Going there
single-handed does not indeed find favour with me."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 17
Content: "Having lost his advantage, who would feel inclined to reduce to submission, an
enemy, who is rich in advantage and determined to lay down his life, as an ordinary person?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 18
Content: "O Kumbhakarna, the foremost among the demons! How do you wish to combat with Rama,
with whom none in the human beings is equal and who is equal of Indra and the sun?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 19
Content: Having thus spoken to the enraged Kumbhakarna, Mahodara on his part spoke as

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64

Content: "Why are you delaying further, after having captured Seetha already? If you do so

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 21
Content: "Some strategy has been discovered by me, as a means of bringing her round. If it is
found agreeable to your intellect, then listen to it.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 22
Content: "Announce (by a beat of drum in the city-streets) that myself, Dvijihva, Samhraadi,

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 23
Content: "Thereupon, having gone to the battle field deliberately, we shall give him a fight.
If we conquer your enemies, there is no need for any strategies to us."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64

----------------------------------------

----------------------------------------

----------------------------------------

----------------------------------------

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 30
Content: "When this thick rumour has gone to all sides that Rama along with his companions

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 32
Content: "By this false pretence, creating fear and anguish, Seetha who thinks she lost her

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 33
Content: "Believing that her charming husband is destroyed, Seetha from her hopelessness and
feminine feeling of flexibility, will come to your will."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 34
Content: "Seetha, who grew up with comfort, who is deserving of happiness; but emaciated with
grief, knowing that her happiness depends on you, will by all means come near to you."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 35
Content: "After contemplating very well, I have conveyed like this. As soon as you see Rama,
a calamity will happen. While you stay here itself without fighting, you will obtain a great
benefit of happiness. Do not become restless."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 64
Verse: 36
Content: "O king! An emperor who conquers his enemies without losing his army, without
meeting with danger and without a combat will obtain for long, a great fame, merit, prosperity and

Chapter: 65
Verse: 1
Content: Hearing the words of Mahodara, Kumbhakarna rebuked him and then spoke to his
brother, Ravana, the chief of demons (as follows):
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 2
Content: "By annihilation of that evil-minded Rama, I will wipe-off your terrifc fear today.
Be happy, indeed without any enmity."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 3
Content: "Warriors do not roar in vain as waterless clouds. Hear my roar, only on completion
of my said task in battle."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 4
Content: "Warriors do not indulge in eulogizing themselves. They do difficult acts, without a
show."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 5
Content: "O Mahodara! Your words may be agreeable to those kings who are confused, who fancy
themselves as the learned, and who themselves are stupid."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 6
Content: "You are all cowards in battle. You always speak pleasantly and go according to the
wishes of the king. You, as such, have spoiled all the undertakings."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 7
Content: "Having access to this king, who has friends merely for a name-sake as also behaving
unfriendly, the treasury got depleted, the army destroyed and king alone is left the Lanka."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 8
Content: "Intent on conquering the enemy, I sally for the battle today to set right your
imprudent policy."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 9
Content: Hearing the words of the intellectual Kumbhakarna, Ravana the king of demons,
bursting into laughter, replied as follows:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 10
Content: "O dear brother, well-versed in the art of war-fare! This Mahodara is frightened of
Rama. There is no doubt. He is not indeed inclined of a war."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 11
Content: "O Kumbhakarna! None is equal to you in friendship and strength, in my eyes. You
march to the battlefield for destroying the enemies and for achieving victory."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 12
Content: "O destroyer of enemies! You, who were sleeping, were awakened by me, for the
purpose of destroying the enemies. This is indeed a grand time for our demons."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 13
Content: "Therefore, go like Yama the god of death, by taking a dart and a noose in your

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 14
Content: "By seeing your very form, the monkeys will run away. The hearts of Rama and
Lakshmana will get broken asunder."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 15
Content: Ravana, the king of demons, having a great energy, thus speaking to the mighty
Kumbhakarna, thought himself as though he was born again.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 16
Content: The king, knowing the strength and prowess of Kumbhakarna, was delighted and became
as bright as the moon.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65, 66
Verse: 17, 17
Content: Some were drowned in the ocean. Some had recourse into the caves. Some others

they were dead.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 18
Content: Kumbhakarna, the annihilator of enemies, speedily took up a sharp spike fully made
of iron, adorned with pure gold and splendidly shining.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 19
Content: Taking hold of that large spike tinted with the blood of enemies, shining like

celestial musicians, Yakshas a class of demi-gods and Nagas the celestial serpents, wreathed in
garlands of crimson flowers with excessive splendour and emitting flames by itself naturally,
Kumbhakarna of great brilliance spoke to Ravana the following words:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 21
Content: "Let this large army stay back here. I shall go all alone. Being angry with hunger,
I shall devour those monkeys now."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 22
Content: Hearing the words of Kumbhakarna, Ravana said, "Go along with army, with their

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 23
Content: "The monkeys, with their huge bodies, valiant, with a much determination and with
their teeth, will destroy anyone who is either alone or off one's guard."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 24
Content: "Therefore, go along with your troops as a person who is very difficult to be
assaulted. Destroy the entire enemy-side, which in inimical to our demons."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 25
Content: Rising up swiftly from his throne, Ravana endowed with a great energy, then placed

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65

Chapter: 65
Verse: 29

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65

Content: Secured with a golden armour, carrying a great load, impenetrable by weapons and as

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 31
Content: Adorned with all ornaments to all his limbs and with a spike in his hand, that demon

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65
Verse: 33
Content: Ravana sent off the mighty Kumbhakarna, having a colossal body, who was then

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65

Content: With loud sounds of counches and kettle-drums, with an army wielding excellent

----------------------------------------

Content: Many demons, possessing a great energy and great strength, with terrific forms and

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65

Chapter: 65

Content: Kumbhakarna with his colossal body and a huge mouth, looking like a scorched hill,

----------------------------------------

Content: "Charged with anger, I shall burn up those troops of the foremost of monkeys, in

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 65

----------------------------------------

in battle because of the inviolability of his armour.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 71
Verse: 98
Content: Atikaya released an arrow having a serpent-like form on Lakshmana. Struck by that
arrow on his vital parts, that Lakshmana, the tormentator of his enemies, felt unconscious just for
a moment.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 71
Verse: 99
Content: Having regained his consciousness, the mighty Lakshmana, the annihilator of enemies,

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 71
Verse: 101
Content: Free from flurry, that Lakshmana, the son of Sumitra, released those arrows, exactly
aiming at that demon, for the purpose of killing him.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 71
Verse: 102
Content: Lakshmana, the best among men, was not able to afflict any injury to Atikaya in

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 71
Verse: 103
Content: "He, endowed with a boon by Brahma the lord of creation, is cloaked by inviolable

Atikaya, with that armour, cannot be destroyed by other missiles."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 71
Verse: 104
Content: Then, hearing the words of the wind-god, Lakshmana having a prowess equal to that of

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 71
Verse: 105
Content: While fixing that excellent missile on that superior sharp-pointed arrow by

Chapter: 71
Verse: 106
Content: Having charged the missile of Brahma on that arrow with the feathers and all, equal

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 71
Verse: 107

Chapter: 71

Chapter: 71

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 71
Verse: 113

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 71
Verse: 114
Content: As their leader was dead, the demons were then frightened and becoming indifferent

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 71
Verse: 115
Content: When the dangerous demon with the terrific strength was killed, the multitude of

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 71
Verse: 116
Content: Throwing down in battle, that Atikaya who was exceedingly strong and looking like a

Chapter: 72
Verse: 1
Content: Hearing Atikaya having been killed in the hands of the great-souled Lakshmana,

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 72
Verse: 2

and valiant demons longing for battle, who conquer the adversaries, who was never defeated in
battle by the enemies they along with their enemies were killed. Many other mighty warriors.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 72
Verse: 5

Rama and Lakshmana, the brothers with terrific arrows, on which boons had been conferred."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 72
Verse: 6
Content: "That terrific bind of arrow cannot be released by any celestial or a mighty demon

by their power or by their sorcery or by their marvel I do not know that."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 72
Verse: 8
Content: "All of those valiant demon-warriors set out for battle, at my command, were killed

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 72

----------------------------------------

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 72

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 72

Chapter: 73
Verse: 1
Content: Then, those surviving troops of demons hastily told Ravana that Devantaka, Trishira,

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 73
Verse: 2
Content: Thereupon, suddenly hearing of those who had been killed, Ravana the prosperous king
of demons, having his eyes filled with profuse tears; boarding over the terrific destroyal of his
son as also the death of his brothers, contemplated for long.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 73
Verse: 3
Content: Then, seeing Ravana the king, miserably submerged in a sea of sorrow, Indrajit,
Ravana's son, the best among charioteers, spoke to him as follows:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 73
Verse: 4
Content: "O father, the king of demons! You ought not to get embarrassed, while Indrajit is
alive. Anyone who is struck by Indrajit's arrows cannot indeed protect his life."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 73
Verse: 5
Content: "Today, you will see Rama along with Lakshmana, with their bodies undistinguished,
scattered and dead, lying down on the floor, with their limbs diffused all over."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 73
Verse: 6
Content: "Listen to Indrajit's promise, which is very firm, backed by valour and divine
blessing. Now itself, I will overwhelm Rama together with Lakshmana unfailing flood of arrows.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 73
Verse: 7
Content: "Now itself, Indra, Yama, Vishnu, Rudra, Sadhyas (a class of celestial beings), the
fire-god, the sun and the moon can see my unlimited prowess, like the terrific prowess of Vishnu
(in his dwarf incarnation as Vamana) in the enclosure where a sacrifice was being performed by
Bali, the demon-king."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 73
Verse: 8
Content: Thus speaking, that Indrajit, with an undepressed mind, after seeking permission
from the king, mounted his chariot with a speed equal to that of wind and yoked with excellent
donkeys.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 73
Verse: 9
Content: That greatly resplendent Indrajit, the annihilator of enemies, having ascended a
chariot looking like the chariot of the sun, quickly went to the battle-front.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 73
Verse: 10
Content: Many mighty demons with terrific prowess, with joy, holding excellent bows in their

Chapter: 73
Verse: 14
Content: That valiant Indrajit swiftly went to the battle-field with full blasts of couches

Chapter: 73

Content: Indrajit, the tormentator of enemies, with a parasol white as a couch and the moon,

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 73
Verse: 16
Content: The valiant Indrajit, the foremost among all the wielders of bow and decked with

Chapter: 73
Verse: 17
Content: Seeing that son setting out with a large army, that glorious Ravana, the king of

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 73

Chapter: 73

Chapter: 73

Chapter: 74

Content: Then, the highly lamenting Lakshmana, having embraced that ailing Rama in his arms,

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 14
Content: "O venerable brother! Virtue cannot save you, who are sticking to the noble path and

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 15
Content: "Just as inanimate and animate beings are visible, likewise virtue and vice are not
visible. Therefore, my opinion is that virtue is non-existent."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 16
Content: "Even as inanimate beings and animate beings are expressly visible, likewise this
form of virtue of vice is not established. For, in that case, a virtuous man like you would not
have this misfortune."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 17
Content: "If unrighteousness had been effective, Ravana should have obtained the hell. You,
endowed with virtue, would never obtain such troubles."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 18
Content: "Since there is absence of calamity for Ravana and misfortune occurred to you, the
result of vice is obtained through virtue and the result of virtue is obtained through vice. The
contraries of each other have changed the roles with each other."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 19
Content: Will the fruit of virtue be obtained through virtue and fruit of vice through vice?
If that in whom unrighteousness is rooted are enjoined with the fruit of unrighteousness alone,
people showing interest in unrighteousness would be deprived of the fruit of virtue. The fruit of
virtue alone would have accrued to those who administer righteousness through that virtue?
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 21
Content: Since prosperities of those, in whom unrighteousness is rooted, develop; while those
who have a conduct of virtue suffer, hence these two (virtue and vice) are useless.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 22
Content: "O Rama! If sinful doers are killed by their own vice, that unrighteousness, as it
does, in the act of killing, will be forthwith destroyed. Whom will that unrighteousness destroy
(which is destroyed in the course of three seconds)?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 23
Content: "Or if a man is killed by a recourse to a ritual prescribed in the scriptures or
kills another (by recourse to such a ritual), that destiny alone, which is engendered by that
ritual, is tainted by that sinful act and not the agent."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 24
Content: "O Rama, the destroyer of adversaries! It is not clear how prosperity can be reached
by righteousness, which has never known how to retaliate. Hence, righteousness seems to be
non-existent."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 25
Content: "O chief among the virtuous! If righteousness were really there, no evil whatever
would have accrued to you. As you reaped such a calamity, the hypotheses that the destiny
engendered by virtuous acts is real is not proved."*
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 26
Content: "Or else, if righteousness becomes weak and cowardly, as it surrenders to the might,
it is my opinion that the righteousness, which lacks strength and has been deprived of its
capacity, should no longer be pursued."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 27
Content: "Depend on might, as you do now on virtue, if the virtue is subordinate to might,
thus giving up predominance of virtue."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 28
Content: "O tormentator of enemies! Or else, if speaking truth were indeed a virtue, our

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 29
Content: "O tormentator of your enemies! Had either righteousness or unrighteousness worth

----------------------------------------

Content: "O Rama! Virtue destroys enemies, when united with might (something other than
virtue). O Rama! A man does all this, according to his will."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 31
Content: "O Rama in a pitiable condition. My opinion is that righteousness consists in such
recourse to both virtue and strength. The very roots of virtue (in the form of earthly gain) have

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83
Verse: 32
Content: "By the treasures brought from place to place and augmented by means of various

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 83

Chapter: 83

Chapter: 83
