Chapter: 84
Verse: 1
Content: While Lakshmana, who was so fond of his brother, was consoling Rama, Vibhishana,
keeping the troops of simian army in their respective positions, arrived there.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 2
Content: That Vibhishana, surrounded by four warriors, wielding many types of weapons, and
who were chiefs of troops, looking like heaps of black collyrium and who were appearing like
elephants, approached Lakshmana who was totally engrossed in sorrow and saw the monkeys also, whose
eyes were filled with tears.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 4
Content: Vibhishana also saw the great-souled Rama, the delight of Inkshvaku dynasty fallen
into a swoon and resting on the lap of Lakshmana.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 5
Content: On seeing the embarrassed Rama, tormented with grief, that Vibhishana, distressed as
he was in spirits, with agony inside, asked him, "What is this?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 6
Content: Fixing his gaze on Vibhishana's face and looking at Sugreeva and those monkeys,
Lakshmana with tears pouring down, spoke the following words, with a splendid meaning:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 7
Content: "O gentle Sir! Just on hearing through the words of Hanuma, saying that Seetha was
killed by Indrajit, Rama entered into a swoon."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 8
Content: Intercepting the narrating Lakshmana in the middle, Vibhishana spoke the following
amply meaningful words to Rama, who was in an unconscious state.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 9
Content: "I hold that which you have been told by Hanuma with a sorrowful temper, O ruler of
men, to be absurd as the drying up of the sea."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 10
Content: "O the long armed! I know the design of the evil-minded Ravana towards Seetha. He
would never do the killing of Seetha."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 11
Content: "Eventhough begged by me, the well-wisher, several times to give up Seetha, he did
not heed that advice."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 12
Content: "It is neither possible even to see her by recourse to conciliation nor by bestowing
gifts nor by sowing dissention. How is it possible then by a war? By any other strategy, it is
impossible."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 13
Content: "That Indrajit for his part retracted, by hoodwinking the monkeys. O the long armed!
Know that Seetha (who was seemingly killed by him) as illusory."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 14
Content: "After reaching a sanctuary by name Nikumbhila, this Indrajit will pour oblations
into the sacred fire. On returning after pouring oblations into the sacred fire, Indrajit will
prove difficult to be overcome in battle, even by celestials including Indra."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 15
Content: "Certainly, this conjuring trick (in the form of killing an illusory living effigy
of Seetha) was exhibited by him, who was employing his magical art, expecting interruption by the
prowess of the monkeys there."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 16
Content: "While the sacrificial performance is not ended, we shall proceed to that place,
along with an army. O the foremost of men! Give up this improper grief, which has come upon you.
Seeing you tormented with grief, the entire army is sinking into despondency."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 18
Content: "Very exalted as you are in courage, stay you here, confident at heart, and send
Lakshmana with us, who are taking an army along with us."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 19
Content: "This Lakshmana, the eminent prince, can make Indrajit abandon that act of
sacrifice, by employing his sharp arrows. Then, he will be susceptible of being killed."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 20
Content: "Lakshmana's arrows, which are sharp and fiery, with a speed equal to the wings of a
bird, can drink his blood like cruel birds."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 21
Content: "O the long-armed one! Therefore, dispatch Lakshmana having auspicious body-marks
even as Indra the lord of celestials employed the thunderbolt to kill Indrajit."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 22
Content: "O the best of men! It is not appropriate to delay the killing of the enemy any
further now. Therefore, grant permission to Lakshmana to destroy the enemy, as Indra would hurl his
thunderbolt to destroy the enemies of celestials."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 84
Verse: 23
Content: "If that Indrajit, the foremost of demons completes the sacrifice, he would not be
visible even to the celestials and the demons in battle. If he come with a desire to fight, after
ending that sacrifice, the celestials also will feel a great suspicion on their own lives."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 1
Content: Hearing those words of Vibhishana, Rama, agonized as he was with grief, could not
understand clearly what was spoken by that demon.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 2
Content: Then, Rama the conqueror of the cities of enemies, leaning upon his courage, spoke
to Vibhishana who was sitting nearby and in front of the monkeys (as follows):
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 3
Content: "O lord of demons! I wish to hear again those of the words spoken by you. I desire
to hear again, whatever you intend to tell me."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 4
Content: Hearing those words of Rama, spoken very sadly, that Vibhishana who was skilled in
expression, again spoke his words gently as follows:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 5
Content: "O the long armed hero! Immediately after your orders, the marshalling of the troops
was done by me in the manner as enjoined by you."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 6
Content: "All those armies were divided and positioned at all places. Even the commanders of
those divisions were arrayed and distributed according to their ranks."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 7
Content: "O great lord! I have to report to you something further. Listen to it. While you
are lamenting without any cause, we feel painful at our hearts."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 8
Content: "O king! Abandon this lamentation and false grief which came to you. Let your worry,
which augments the pleasure of your adversaries be therefore abandoned."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 9
Content: "O hero! If you want to get back Seetha and if the demons are to be destroyed, raise
up for the occasion. Keep yourself cheerful."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 10
Content: "O Rama! Listen to my benign words I tell you. This Lakshmana together with a large
army should go soon to kill Indrajit, who reached Nikumbhila, with arrows as deadly as the
serpentine poison released from his snake-like bow in battle."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 12
Content: "By his penance, Indrajit obtained a weapon called Brahmashira, by way of a gift
from Brahma and also horses, which are coursing at his will."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 13
Content: "That Indrajit, as such along with his army, is reported to have reached Nikumbhila.
If he comes forth after completing his sacrificial act, know that all of us as killed."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 14
Content: "A boon was given by Brahma to that intelligent demon as follows: "O Indrajit! That
enemy of yours, who strikes while you are marching with your bow drawn, and while you have not
arrived at Nikumbhila, or even while you have not offered oblations to the sacred fire, will prove
to be the cause of your killing."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 16
Content: "O mighty Rama! Give your command for killing of Indrajit. When he is killed, know
that Ravana along with his associate troops also as killed."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 17
Content: Hearing the words of Indrajit, Rama then spoke the following words:"O Vibhishana of
true prowess! I know the conjuring trick of that terrific demon."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 18
Content: "That Indrajit is skilled in the use of the mystic missile presided over by Brahma.
He is intelligent. He is a master of several conjuring tricks. He is so mighty that he can render
unconscious in battle even the gods along with Varuna the king of gods."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 19
Content: "O highly illustrious hero! While he drifts in the sky, ascending his chariot, his
movement is not known to others, as the sun is not seen beneath a dense mass of clouds."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 20
Content: Having known the toughness of the conjuring tricks of the evil-minded adversary,
Rama spoke to the illustrious Lakshmana as follows:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 21
Content: "O Lakshmana! You, accompanied by that entire army which stands at the disposal of
Sugreeva, along with troop-commanders with Hanuma as their head; and protected by Jambavan the lord
of bears, who will be accompanied by his army, kill that Indrajit the prince of demons, rich in the
power of conjuring tricks."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 23
Content: "The great souled Vibhishana, who knows all the conjuring tricks of Indrajit, along
with his counsellors, will follow behind you."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 24
Content: Hearing the words of Rama, Lakshmana of highly wonderful prowess, along with
Vibhishana, took hold of his excellent bow.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 25
Content: The rejoiced Lakshmana who was prepared for the combat, clad in an armour, wielding
a sword and arrows, wearing his bow in his left hand and having touched Rama's feet in salutation,
spoke as follows:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 26
Content: "Today, the arrows released from my bow, piercing Indrajit, will drop into the City
of Lanka, as swans descend into a louts-pond.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 27
Content: "Now itself, my arrows discharged from the bow-string of this great bow, duly
splitting his terrific body, will blow him away."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 28
Content: Thus speaking in front of his brother, that resplendent Lakshmana, quickly marched
forward, with an intent to kill Indrajit.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 29
Content: Offering salutation to the feet of his brother and doing circumambulation too, that
Lakshmana went to the sanctuary named Nikumbhila, which was protected by Indrajit.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 30
Content: Having obtained the blessings from his brother, the glorious Lakshmana, the prince,
quickly sallied forth along with Vibhishana.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 31
Content: Then, Hanuma accompanied by many a thousand of monkeys and Vibhishana along with his
counsellors went behind Lakshmana.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 32
Content: That Lakshmana, quickly surrounded by a large army of monkeys, saw the army of
Jambavan also stationed in the way.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 33
Content: After covering a long distance, that Lakshmana, the delight to his friends, saw the
army of Ravana, ranged in battle-array, from a distance.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 34
Content: Duly arriving at Nikumbhila, that foe-conquering Lakshmana stood, bow in hand, to
conquer that Indrajit, the possessor of conjuring tricks, in conformity with Brahma's
ordinance.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 35
Content: The valiant Lakshmana stood there along with Vibhishana, the heroic Angada and
Hanuma, the son of wind-god.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 85
Verse: 36
Content: Lakshmana penetrated that heterogeneous army of enemies, resplendent with spotless
weapons, thick with ensigns and abounded with huge chariots, exceedingly impenetrable, very
terrific, with unimaginable swiftness, even as one would enter a thick veil of darkness.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 1
Content: In that situation, Vibhishana then spoke the following words, which were hostile to
the enemies and advantageous to Lakshmana.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 2
Content: "Let this army of demons which is seen here, dark as a cloud, be quickly engaged in
battle, by the monkeys using rocks as thier weapons."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 3
Content: "O Lakshmana! Make an effort to break this mighty army. When this army is destroyed,
Indrajit also will become visible."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 4
Content: "You as such, rush forward quickly, gushing out arrows, equal to Indra's
thunderbolt, on the enemies, so long as this sacrificial act of Indrajit is not actually carried
through."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 5
Content: "O hero! Make a short work of Indrajit, the evil minded, who is interested in
performing conjuring tricks, who is unjust, engaged in cruel acts and who brings fear to all the
worlds."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 6
Content: Hearing the words of Vibhishana, Lakshmana, having auspicious marks, showered forth
streams of arrows in the direction of Indrajit.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 7
Content: Bears and monkeys, who fight was gigantic trees, rushed towards that army of demons,
drawn up in battle-array.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 8
Content: The demons too, with an intent to kill the monkeys in battle, attacked them with
sharp arrows, sowrds, spears and javelins.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 9
Content: That tumultuous battle between the monkeys and the demons rendered Lanka noisy on
all sides with its great uproar.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 10
Content: The sky was covered with weapons of various shapes, sharp arrows, trees and tossed
mountain tops.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 11
Content: Those demons of ugly faces and arms, hurling weapons on the monkeys, created a great
fear.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 12
Content: Even the monkeys too struck and killed all the demons in the battle, with various
types of trees and mountain-peaks.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 13
Content: A great fear developed among the demons who were fighting with mighty leaders of
bears and monkeys endowed with colossal bodies.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 14
Content: Hearing that his own army being tormented by the enemies, was dejected; that
unconquerable Indrajit left off, without performing the sacrificial rite.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 15
Content: That enraged Indrajit, coming out from the gloominess of the trees, ascended his
firmly yoked chariot which had already been united
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 16
Content: That awful Indrajit, armed with terrific bow and arrows, looking like a mass of
black collyrium with his blood-red eyes, appeared like the destructive Death.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 17
Content: Just on seeing Indrajit being on a chariot, that army of demons with a terrific
speed, turned back, wishing to fight with Lakshmana.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 18
Content: At that time, Hanuma the destroyer of enemies looking like a mountain, uplifted an
absolutely unpaalleled large tree. Consuming that army of demons, as a fire at the time of
universal dissolution, the aforesaid monkey made that army unconscious on the battle field, with
many trees.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 20
Content: Immediately on seeing Hanuma destroying thier army rapidly, thousands of demons
hurled weapons on him.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 21
Content: Approaching Hanuma looking like a mountain, the demons bearing pointed pikes struck
him from all sides with pkes, those carrying swords in their hands with swords, those carring
javelins in their hands with jalins, with iron rods with maces; those armed with sharp-edged spears
with spears, as also with bright-looking spears, with hundreds of cylindrical wooden pieces studded
with iron spikes, with steel hammers, ,with awful axes, with slings for the rwing stones, with
their thunderbolt-like fists and slaps which fell like flashes of lighning. Then, the enraged
Hanuma made a colossal destruction of those demons.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 25
Content: That Indrajit saw Hanuma, the foremost of monkeys, looking like a mountain,
fearlessly killing his enemies.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 26
Content: He spoke the following words tohis charioteer: "Take the chariot to the place where
that monkey is standing. If we neglect him, he will surely destroy our demons."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 27
Content: Hearing the words of that Indrajit, the charioteer went, carrying that very
unconquerable Indrajit sitting in the chariot, to the place where Hanuma was there.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 28
Content: Coming close to Hanuma, that unconquerable Indrajit hurled swords, sharp-edged
spears and axes on the head of Hanuma.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 29
Content: Receiving those terrible weapons, that Hanuma spoke, seized as he was, with great
rage, the following words:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 30
Content: "O evil-minded Indrajit! If you are valiant, fight with me. Coming nearer to Hanuma,
you will not return alive."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 31
Content: "O foolish fellow! If you enter into a duel with me, fight with your arms. Withstand
my force in the battle-field. Then you will be considered as the best among the demons."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 32
Content: Vibhishana told Lakshmana in the following words that while with bow upraised,
Indrajit sought to kill Hanuma.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 33
Content: "Having seated in a chariot, Indrajit, who conquered Indra, is seeking to kill
Hanuma."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 34
Content: "O Lakshmana! Kill that Indrajit with your terrific arrows of incomparable
workmanship, which ward off the enemies and putting an end to their lives."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 86
Verse: 35
Content: Hearing the words of Vibhishana, who was fearful to his adversaries, the
great-souled Lakshmana saw Indrajit, who closely resembled a mountain, seated in a chariot, of
terrific strength and who was difficult to approach.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 1
Content: After speaking to him as aforesaid, Vibhishana taking Lakshmana, who held a bow in
his hand, felt rejoiced and hastened away.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 2
Content: Moving not very distant from there and entering an extensive thicket, Vibhishana
showed to Lakshmana, the place where Indrajit was going to pour oblations into the sacred fire.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 3
Content: The glorious Vibhishana showed a terribly looking banyan tree, appearing like a
blace cloud (and spoke as follows).
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 4
Content: "After offering oblations to the spirits at this place, the mighty Indrajit proceeds
to the battle afterwards."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 5
Content: "Thereupon, this demon becomes invisible to any one, kills some enemies in battle
and binds some with his excellent arrows."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 6
Content: "Destroy that mighty Indrajit, along with his chariot, horses and charioteer, by
releasing your blazing arrows, even while he has not reached the banyan tree."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 7
Content: That greatly brilliant Lakshmana, a delight of his fiends, saying 'So be it' took
his stand there, twanging his bow at full length.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 8
Content: That Indrajit, the son of Ravana, clad in armour, armed with a sword, and
distinguished by his ensign, appeared in a fire-coloured chariot.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 9
Content: That highly splendid Lakshmana spoke to that Indrajit, the scion of Sage Paulastya,
who had never been conquered before (as follows); "I am inviting you for a fight. Give battle to me
in a right manner."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 10
Content: Thus spoken by Lakshmana, Indrajit with a great brilliance and high mindedness,
seeing Vibhishana there, spoke the following harsh words to him:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 11
Content: "O demon! You are born and brought up here. You are a direct brother to my father
and a paternal uncle to me. How can you be hostile to a son?
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 12
Content: "O perverted fellow, an abuser of righteousness! Consanguinity is not a norm for
you, nor friendliness, nor pride of birth, nor a brotherly feeling nor a right conduct."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 13
Content: "O evil-minded one! You are pitiable and deserve to be reproached by the virtuous,
in that having abandoned your onw kind, you have entered into the service of our enemy."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 14
Content: "You are not recognizing the great difference because of your feeble mind. Where is
living together with one's own kindred and where is taking refuge with low kind of enemies?
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 15
Content: "Opponents may be virtuous. One's own kindred may not be virtuous. But, a relation,
though bereft of merit is preferable. An enemy is, indeed, ever an enemy."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 16
Content: "He who, abandoning his own side, takes sides with adversary, is killed, after his
own knsmen are destroyed just by those people of the other side."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 17
Content: "O Indrajit, the demon! The ruthlessness thus shown by you and the manliness
exhibited by you (in bringing Lakshmana here) could be possible only by you, our own kindred."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 18
Content: Hearing the words of Indrajit, his brother's son, Vibhishana replied: "O demon! Why
do you speak perversely, as though you are not aware of my nature."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 19
Content: "O Indrajit the wicked one! Atleast out of respect for the elders, abandon your
harshness. Even if I am born in a demoniac race, which does cruel acts, my nature is goodness,
which is prime virtue of human beings and it is not demoniacal."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 20
Content: "I neither delight in cruel acts, nor rejoice in unvirtuous acts. How can a brother
be driven away by his brother, even if the former's nature is different?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 21
Content: "Renouncing a man of sinful resolve hose conduct has deviated from righteousness,
one attains happiness, as one shakes off a venomous serpent from his hand."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 22
Content: "The wise men say that an evil-natured fellow, who is intent on taking away other's
property and lustfully touches another's wife, is worth shunning, as one abandons a house in
flames."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 23
Content: "Three faults produce destruction. Taking away other's property, lustfully touching
another's wife and excessive distrust with one's friends."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 24
Content: "These faults which destroy one's life and lordship killing great sages terribly,
waging war against all celestials, arrogance, becoming angry very easily, quarrelsomeness, ill-will
have concealed the good qualities of my elder brother, as the clouds conceal the view of
mountains."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 26
Content: "Because of these vices, Ravana, your father and my brother, has been abandoned by
me. Neither will this City of Lanka will exist any longer nor you nor your father."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 27
Content: "O demon! You can talk to me as you like, since you are arrogant, foolish,
indisciplined and caught, as you are, in the noose of Death."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 28
Content: "O the worst of demons! You got this calamity here because you spoke harsh words to
me today. You cannot reach the banyan-tree any longer."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 29
Content: "It is not possible for you to survive, on attacking Lakshmana. You fight with
Lakshmana, the lord of men, in the battle-field. After being killed, you will do sacred work in the
abode of Yama, the god of Death."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 87
Verse: 30
Content: "Do spend away all your weapons and arrows, by showing your own augmented strength.
Reaching the range of Lakshmana's arrows, you will not indeed return alive with your army
today."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 1
Content: Hearing the words of Vibhishana, Indrajit was excited with rage, spoke harsh words
and rushed forward in fury.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 2
Content: Indrajit was looking like Yama the lord of Death at the time of dissolution of the
world, sitting in a well-decorated and distinguished chariot yoked with black horses, having
upraised sword and weapons, raising a big terrific enormous strong and swift bow and laying hold of
arrows which can torment the enemies.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 4
Content: The mighty the destroyer of adversaries, wielding a large bow, fully adorned, and
seated in a chariot saw that Lakshmana who was embellished with his own splendor.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 5
Content: Indrajit hurriedly spoke to those foremost of monkeys and to this Lakshmana, who
ascended Hanuma's back with a splendor of the sun shining on Mount Udaya and also with Vibhishana
as follows: "You behold my prowess now."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 6
Content: "Now, you can face an unconquerable stream of arrows, like rain, released in the
sky, as discharged from my bow in the battle-field."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 7
Content: "Today my arrows released from my large bow will destroy your bodies, as fire
consumes a pile of cotton."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 8
Content: "Today, I will send all of you to the world of Yama the lord of Death, by piercing
you with my sharp arrows and hurling the pikes, javelins and lances on you."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 9
Content: "Who can stand before me, while I release streams of arrows with my swift-hand in
battle, thundering like a cloud?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 10
Content: "Earlier on that day, in a nocturnal battle, both of you along with Sugreeva and
other followers, were made unconscious by my arrows which were like thunderbolts and tips of
missiles as also you were made to fall down on the floor."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 11
Content: "Do you not have that remembrance? I presume clearly that you are on the road to
Yama the lord of Death, since you have come to give battle to me, enraged as I am, like a venomous
serpent."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 12
Content: Enraged in hearing that roaring of Indrajit, Lakshmana then spoke the following
words, with a courageous countenance.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 13
Content: "O demon! It has been proclaimed by you about the successful conclusion of your
tasks, eventhough it is difficult to achieve them. He alone is clever, whoever carries through his
undertakings in practice."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 14
Content: "O evil-minded one! You are thinking that you have accomplished your end, by
proclaiming through word alone, the achievement of your end, which is difficult to attain for
anyone, though you, as such, lack in capacity to achieve your purpose."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 15
Content: "The path, which was followed on that day by you, becoming invisible in the
battle-field, is the one trodden by thieves and is not the path followed by valiant ones."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 16
Content: "O demon! Having reached the range of your arrows, I am standing before you.
Therefore show your prowess today. Why should you brag with your words?
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 17
Content: Hearing those words, the mighty Indrajit, victorious in battle, reaching his
terrific bow, released sharp arrows from it.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 18
Content: Duly reaching Lakshmana, the arrows released by Indrajit, which rushed with great
speed and were as deadly as the venom of serpents, fell like the hissing of snakes.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 19
Content: The swift Indrajit, the son of Ravana, with his arrows of very great velocity, in
that battle, struck Lakshmana who was endowed with auspicious body-marks.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 20
Content: That glorious Lakshmana, drenched in blood, with his body very much wounded by
arrows, shone like a smokeless flame.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 21
Content: Mulling over his own feat, Indrajit for his part, approaching Lakshmana and emitting
an exceedingly loud roar, spoke the following words:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 22
Content: "The sharp-edged and deadly arrows, with their wings, released from my bow, will now
take your life, O Lakshmana!"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88
Verse: 23
Content: "O Lakshmana! Let a number of Jackals, multitude of hawks and vultures descend upon
you, when struck down by me, you are dead."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 88

Chapter: 107

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 107

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 107
Verse: 13
Content: That standard, mounted on Ravana's chariot, having been torn off, fell on the

as he was, with the power of wrath.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 107
Verse: 15
Content: Ravana struck Rama's horses with blazing arrows. Those divine horses were neither

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 107
Verse: 16
Content: Seeing those horses unstumbled, Ravana then was very much enraged and released

Chapter: 107
Verse: 21

Chapter: 107
Verse: 23

Chapter: 107
Verse: 25

Chapter: 107

Chapter: 107
Verse: 28
Content: Those two extremely enraged warriors in this way, carried out are excellent combat.

Chapter: 107

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 107
Verse: 50
Content: At that time, those gods along with troops of sages, saying "May all be well with

Chapter: 107
Verse: 52
Content: Seeing that matchless struggle and observing that the sky is its own compeer and the

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 107
Verse: 54
Content: Thereupon, the great-armed Rama who augmented the fame of the kings born in Raghu

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 107
Verse: 56

Chapter: 107

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 107

Chapter: 107
Verse: 59
Content: Yet, no certainty about Ravana's death could be seen. Thought equipped with many

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 107
Verse: 60
Content: "What is the reason, these arrows by which Mareecha, Khara, Dushana, Kabandha in

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 107

Content: Thus absorbed in thought, Rama remained vigilant in the battle-field. He showered

Chapter: 107

Chapter: 107

Chapter: 108
Verse: 1

Content: "O lord! You can employ a mystic missile presided over by Brahma the lord of

Chapter: 108
Verse: 3
Content: Then, the valiant Rama, who was reminded thus by Matali, took hold of a blazing

Chapter: 108
Verse: 5

Chapter: 108
Verse: 6

Verse: 7

Chapter: 108
Verse: 8
Content: Blazing like a fire at the time of universal dissolution enveloped in smoke and

Content: It broke gate-ways, iron bars, and even mountains. Smeared witht he blood of various

Chapter: 108

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 1
Content: Seeing his brother lying down dead after defeat in battle, Vibhishana lamented, with
his mind filled with an outburst of sorrow:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 2
Content: "Why are you lying killed on the ground, though you are highly worthy of turning
towards lofty beds, O hero! The valiant one, the celebrated one, prudent in polity?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 3
Content: "Having thrown about your two long arms which though decked wit armlets, are now
motionless and with your diadem brilliant as the sun, knocked down; why are you lying killed on the
ground/"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 4
Content: "O the valiant brother! That which was told by me earlier and that which was not
liked by you, as you were overcome with sensuality and infatuation; that very fate has been
obtained by you."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 5
Content: "For that which, because of arrogance, neither Prahasta nor Indrajit and others, nor
Kumbhakarna nor Atiratha nor Narantaka nor you yourself has agreed to my counsel, the consequence
of it has come now."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 6
Content: "As this hero, the foremost of those who wield the weapons, has fallen on the
ground, the established rule of well-conducted persons has gone. The incarnation of virtue has

has fallen to the earth. The moon has merged in darkness. Fire has extinguished its flames and a
strennous effort has become inactive."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 8
Content: "What is remaining in this world now, while Ravana the foremost of demons, is at
present lying fast asleep in the dust?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 9
Content: "With firmness for its shoot, endurance for its excellent blossom, asceticism for
its strength, and valour for its firm root, the large tree in the shape of Ravana has been crushed

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 10
Content: "With sharpness for its tusks, the line of ancestors for its back-bone, anger for

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 11
Content: "With prowess and power for its expanded flames, sighs for its smoke and his native
strength for its glowing heat, the blazing fire in the shape of Ravana the demon has been

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 12
Content: "With the demons for its tail; hump and horn and fickleness for its ears and eyes,

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 13
Content: To Vibhishana, who was thus speaking; enveloped in sorrow, Rama spoke the following
words, full of reason and which revealed his determined view of the matter.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 14
Content: "Ravana did not die in battle, without making an effort. He has fallen in combat,
eventhough he was endowed with terrible prowess and exhibited extra ordinary enthusiasm of a very
exalted type and remained confident throughout."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 15
Content: "There is no occasion to grieve for him having fallen into death in the battle-field
and by whom the development of his country was wished for, while remaining steadfast in the duty of
Kshatriya the warrior."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 16
Content: "There is no occasion to grieve for his having been brought under the sway of death
by whom intelligent as he was, all the three worlds including indra were frightened."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 17
Content: "In the past, none has ever been exclusively victorious in a combat. A hero either
has been killed by his adversaries or had killed the enemies in battle."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 18
Content: "Such is the destiny proclaimed by the ancients, as highly esteemed for a warrior. A
warrior killed in battle, does not deserve to be mourned. Such is the ascertainment of the sacred
scriptures."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 19
Content: "Therefore, seeing this ascertainment, understanding the true principle, and free
from grief, think here of what duty that deserves to be performed."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 20
Content: To that valiant prince (Rama) by whom the aforesaid words were spoken, Vibhishana,

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 21
Content: "The demon, who had never been conquered before in battles, by even all the gods

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 22

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 24
Content: Thus getting the personality of Ravana well-acquainted by vibhishana by his

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 109
Verse: 25
Content: "Hostilities end with death. Our purpose has been accomplished. Let his funeral
rites be performed. He is even as good mine, as yours."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 1
Content: Seeing Ravana killed by the great-souled Rama, the female-demons were stricken with
grief and rushed out from their gynaecium.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 2

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 3
Content: Issuing out of the northern gate along with demons and penetrating into the terrific

rendered muddy with blood."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 5
Content: Those women, who were overcome with grief about the death of their husband, having

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 6
Content: Those women saw the gigantic Ravana, who was endowed with a great strength and

Verse: 7
Content: Suddenly seeing their husband lying in dust of the battle-field, those women fell

----------------------------------------

and another, catching hold of his neck.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110

----------------------------------------

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110

Content: "That Ravana, by whom Indra was thrown into fear, Yama was struck with terror, by

killed in the battle-field."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 14
Content: "This danger has come from a mortal to him, who did not conceive any fear from the
demons or the gods or even the serpents for that matter!"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 15
Content: "Here lies killed in battle, by a pedestrian man coming from Ayodhya, that Ravana,
who was incapable of being killed by gods and even so by devils and demons too."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 16
Content: "He who could not be killed by gods, Yakshas and demons alike, could be killed by a
mortal like one devoid of strength."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 17

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 18
Content: "For your own death, Seetha was borne away by you, who did not listen to your near

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 19
Content: "Though tendering salutary advice to you, Vibhishana your beloved brother, was

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 20
Content: "If you had restored Seetha a princess of Mithila to Rama, this appallingly terrific

Chapter: 110

Content: "If you had restored Seetha to Rama, Vibhishana your brother would have had his

Chapter: 110
Verse: 22

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 23
Content: "O the excellent demon! Your act of following your own free will, may not be the

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 24
Content: "This destruction of the monkeys, your demons as also yourself, in the battle, has

Chapter: 110
Verse: 25
Content: "The course of destiny, when ready to bear fruit, cannot be diverted either by
money, or by wish, or by valour or even by command in this world."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 110
Verse: 23
Content: Those consorts of Ravana, depressed as they were and afflicted with grief, with
their eyes full of tears, thus lamented like female ospreys.

Chapter: 111
Verse: 24
Content: "O my lord, who annihilated yourself and your people! Seetha is the model of

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 111

Chapter: 111
Verse: 33
Content: "I, however, whose stock of merit was deficient, have fallen into a terrific ocean

of your death. Though the same, I stand transformed into another as it were. Woe be to the
flickering fortunes of kings!"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 111
Verse: 36
Content: "Alas, O king! That face of yours which was so tender, O lord, and distinguished by

luster, was illumined by a number of diadems, which shone with its eyes wild and rolling through
inebriety in banqueting places, bore garlands of various kinds, was lovely and charming in every
way, was lit with a captivating smile and indulged in a delightful talk - that face of yours does
not actually shine as before today pierced with Rama's arrows, it lies dyed with streams of blood.
It has its marrow shattered and has got soiled through the dust raised by the chariots."
----------------------------------------

Content: "Alas! The last stage of my life, which conferred widow ship on me, has come and

Chapter: 111
Verse: 44
Content: "O king! The body of yours which was really dark as glossy sapphire, gigantic like a

difficult for me to touch it again, it is no longer possible to embrace it. It has tendons cut to
pieces, by arrows of Rama, dug deep into your vital parts and closely transfixed like the spines of
a porcupine. Though dark of complexion, it is now transformed into the colour of blood and lies

Chapter: 113

Chapter: 113
Verse: 9

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 113
Verse: 11
Content: "Ravana, the enemy was killed. Even the Lanka has been subdued. With a firm

Chapter: 113

Chapter: 113

Chapter: 113

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 113
Verse: 35
Content: "I wish to kill the female-demons, who have spoken harsh words to you and wronged

----------------------------------------

Content: "O illustrious lady! Striking them with several blows in this way, I would destroy

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 113

Content: Reflecting as pondering for a while, when spoke thus by Hanuma, the compassionate

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 113

Content: "All this is reaped by me, as a consequence of my bad fortune or an account of a

Chapter: 113

Content: "O the great-armed Hanuma! Do not speak like this. This is indeed a great divine

Content: "O Hanuma! As commanded by Ravana the threatened me. As he is dead now, they will

----------------------------------------

Content: "A superior person does not take into account the sin of those who have committed an

Chapter: 116
Verse: 22
Content: No one near and dear was indeed able to cajole on that occasion or to speak or even
to look upon Rama, who appeared like Yama the lord of death at the time of dissolution of the
world.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 23
Content: Thereupon, Seetha, after doing circumambulation to Rama, who was standing with his
head bent low, proceeded towards the blazing fire.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 24
Content: Having offered salutation to gods and brahmins as also having joined her palms in
the vicinity of the fire, Seetha spoke the following words:
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 25
Content: "As my heart never moves off from Rama, so let the fire-god, the witness of the
world, protect me from all sides."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 26
Content: "As Rama apprehends me, though of unimpeachable conduct, to be spoilt, let the
fire-god the witness of the world protect me from all sides."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 27
Content: "As I have never been unfaithful in act, thought and speech to Rama, who knows all
the virtues, so let the fire-god protect me."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 28
Content: "Since the adorable sun-god, wind-god, the four quarters and even so the moon-god,
as also the deity presiding over the day-time and the twilights and the night and the earth and
even others know me to be endowed with good conduct, so let the fire-god protect me."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 29
Content: Thus speaking, Seetha walking around the fire-god, with her mind free from
hesitation, entered the blazing fire.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 30
Content: A large gathering of men including children and elders, saw the shining Seetha
having entered the fire there.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 31
Content: That Seetha, with the shining of fresh refined gold and decked with ornaments of
refined gold, plunged into the blazing fire, in the presence of all people.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 32
Content: All the living beings saw then that wide-eyed Seetha, who looked like a golden
altar, plunging into the fire.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 33
Content: The sages, gods, and the Gandharvas saw that illustrious Seetha entering deep into

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 34
Content: All the women (who were present there) screamed on seeing her, rushing into the

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 35
Content: The denizens of the entire three worlds including the gods, Gandharvas and demons,

hell.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 116
Verse: 36
Content: While she was entering deeply into the fire, a loud sound, which appeared strange,
uttering 'Alas, Alas' rose both from the demons and the monkeys alike.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 1
Content: Hearing the cries of these who were thus wailing, the virtuous minded Rama then
became thoughtful for a while, afflicted as he was with melancholy, his eyes filled with tears.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 2
Content: Thereupon, Kubera the King of Yakshas, Yama the lord of death together with the

reaching the City of Lanka in aerial cars, shining like the sun approached Rama.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 5
Content: Lifting their long arms, their hands decked with ornaments, those excellent gods
thereupon, spoke (as follows) to Rama who stood there, making a respectful salutation to them with
his folded hands.
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 6
Content: "How do you, the maker of the entire cosmos, the foremost among those endowed with
knowledge and an all-capable person, ignore Seetha who is falling into the fire? How do you not
recognize yourself to be the foremost of the troop of gods?"
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 7
Content: "Among the Vasus (a class of gods, eight in number), you are the Vasu, named
R^itadhama (one whose abode is Truth or the Divine Law) who was formerly the self-constituted
ruler, the first creator of all the three worlds and the lord of creatures."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 8
Content: "You are the eighth Rudra among (eleven) Rudras and the fifth (Viryavan by name)

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 9
Content: "O the destroyer of the adversaries. You are seen (to exist) at the beginning and at
the end of creation. Yet, you ignore Seetha, just like a common man."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 10
Content: Hearing the words of those guardians of the world, Rama, the lord of creation, who

----------------------------------------

Verse: 11
Content: "I think of myself to be a human being, by name Rama, the son of Dasaratha. You, as

Content: Hearing the words of Rama, Brahma (the creator), the foremost among the knowers of

Chapter: 117
Verse: 13
Content: "You are the Lord Narayana himself the glorious god, who wields the discus. You are

Chapter: 117
Verse: 14
Content: "You are Brahma, the imperishable, the Truth abiding in the middle as well as at the

Chapter: 117
Verse: 15
Content: "You are the wielder of a bow called Sarnga, the lord of the senses, the supreme

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 16
Content: "You are the leader of the army and the village headman. You are the intellect. You

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 17
Content: "You perform action for Indra the lord of celestials, the Supreme Ruler, the one

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 18
Content: "In the form of the Vedas, you are the great Bull with hundred heads (rules) and

endowed with mystic powers by virtue of their very birth) and Sadhyas (a class of celestial

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 20
Content: "You are the sacrificial performance. You are the sacred syllable 'Vashat' (on

origin nor who you are in reality."
----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 21
Content: "You appear in all created beings in the cattle and in brahmanas. You exist in all

Chapter: 117

Verse: 23

Chapter: 117
Verse: 24
Content: "O Rama! I (brahma) am your heart. Saraswathi, the goddess (of learning) is your

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 25
Content: "Night has been recognized as the closing of your eye-lids and the day, as the

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 117
Verse: 26
Content: "The entire cosmos is your body. The earth constitutes your firmness. Fire is your

Chapter: 117
Verse: 27

Chapter: 117

Content: Hearing those words, the courageous Rama of great prowess and the foremost of those

Chapter: 118
Verse: 20
Content: "Seetha, the daughter of Janaka, is completely pure in her character, in all the

Chapter: 118

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 124

Chapter: 125

Content: That swift-moving Hanuma, with his rejoicingly feather-like body and with a great

Chapter: 125

Chapter: 125
Verse: 27
Content: Going quickly for a long distance, that foremost of the monkeys reached trees in

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 125
Verse: 29
Content: At a distance of two miles from Ayodhya Hanuama saw Bharata, living in a hermitage,

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 125
Verse: 34
Content: Those citizens, who were all fond of righteousness, were not willing to enjoy

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 125
Verse: 35
Content: With joined palms in salutation, Hanuma the son of wind-god spoke as follows to that

Chapter: 125

Chapter: 125

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 125

----------------------------------------

Content: "I am indeed hearing a delight mention of my lord, who proceeded to the vast forest

----------------------------------------

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 126
Verse: 5
Content: "O Lord, the long-armed! How your mother was conferred with two boons by your

----------------------------------------

Chapter: 126

Content: "When you had gone away, that forest (of Chitrakuta) then assumed a very miserable
